trial_identification.scientifictitle: A cohort observational study to assay natriuretic peptide levels in people who have had a Myocardial Infarction (MI) to determine if they are better prognostic indicators of death and all cardiovascular events after acute MI than other indices as well as a better reflection of the left ventricular function as assessed by Radionuclide Ventriculography

interventions.interventions: natriuretic peptide levels 24-96 hours post myocardial infarction and at 3-5 months and 12 months post discharge

primaryOutcome.outcome: Natriuretic peptide levels are better prognostic indicators of death and all cardiovascular events after acute myocardial infarction than other indices
primaryOutcome.timepoint: 24 - 96 hours post MI and at 3 - 5 months and 12 months post discharge

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Natriuretic peptide levels better reflect left ventricular function.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed by radionuclide ventriculography and/or echocardiography24-96 hours post myocardial infarction and at 3-5 months and 12 months post discharge.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Diagnosis of MI24-96h from symptoms onsetMale or female18-80 years of ageCK =400u/L.andchest pain or other symptoms suggesting myocardial ischaemiaorST elevation of = 1mm in 2 contigous ECG leadsor New pathological Q waves.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This is an cohort observational study to assess whether natriuretic peptide levels are better prognostic indicators of death and all cardiovascular events after acute myocardial infarction than other indices, and also better reflect left ventricular function as assessed by radionuclide ventriculography and/or echocardiography. Measurements will be carried out, within 24-96 hours of onset of chest pain and again at 3-5 months and 12 months after acute infarction. Clinical History will be recorded for 5 years
